embed.title: Quest 2 Straps
embed.description: Please select a strap below for more information, or 'summary' for an overview.

embeds.title: Quest Straps
embeds.description: The Quest 2 does support modular straps, and as such lots of accessories exist, in the dropdown below you can see details on the straps listed below including photos.

fields.name: Bobo M2
fields.value: The Bobo M2  is a Halo style strap that's well known.

fields.name: Bobo M2 Pro
fields.value: The Bobo M2 Pro is a Halo style strap that has a built in battery that's well known.

fields.name: Kiwi Elite Strap
fields.value: The Kiwi Elite Strap is a elite strap style strap that doesn't have the same cracking issue as the official strap, and is known to be comfortable.

fields.name: Vive Deluxe Audio Strap
fields.value: The Vive Deluxe Audio Strap is a solution using a strap designed for a Vive with integrated audio, but is quite costly.

embeds.title: Bobo M2
embeds.description:
The Bobo M2 is a 'Halo' Style strap that's very common in the communinity.

It can be found in multiple regions, and is generally known to be a good overall choice for comfort and value.

fields.name: Info
fields.value:
__Included Battery__: No 
 __Included Audio__: No

fields.name: Store Links
fields.value: [Amazon USA](https://www.amazon.com/BOBOVR-M2-Replacement-Pressure-Comfortable/dp/B08YR8LFH3) [Amazon Canada](https://www.amazon.ca/BOBOVR-M2-Adjustable-Cushion%EF%BC%8CReplacement-Strap%EF%BC%8CIncrease/dp/B093WNWZRR/) [Amazon UK](https://www.amazon.co.uk/BOBOVR-Replacement-Accessories-Adjustable-Pressure-M2-Strap/dp/B094J91ST9) [AliExpress](https://www.aliexpress.com/i/1005002558081445.html)

embeds.title: Bobo M2 Pro
embeds.description:
The Bobo M2 PRO is a 'Halo' Style strap that's relatively new, its a sucessor to the Bobo M2, but has an included hotswappable battery.

It's a bit harder to find due to the battery, but is generally known to be a good overall choice for comfort and value compared to other options like the Elite Battery Strap.

fields.name: Info
fields.value:
__Included Battery__: Yes 
 __Included Audio__: No

fields.name: Store Links

embeds.title: Kiwi Elite Strap
embeds.description:
The Kiwi Elite Strap is an upgraded elite strap style strap with a nice cushioned top and head cushion.
 One of the main benefits of this is the fact it's able to fit in the official case and third party cases.

fields.name: Info
fields.value:
__Included Battery__: No 
 __Included Audio__: No

fields.name: Store Links
fields.value: [Amazon USA](https://www.amazon.com/KIWI-design-Accessories-Enhanced-Support/dp/B098JTDPQC) [Amazon Canada](https://www.amazon.ca/KIWI-design-Upgraded-Enhanced-Support/dp/B098JTDPQC) [UK](https://www.amazon.co.uk/KIWI-design-Upgraded-Accessories-Enhanced-Head-Strap/dp/B098JTDPQC), [AliExpress](https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1005003162851232.html)

embeds.title: Vive Deluxe Audio Strap
embeds.description:
The Vive Deluxe Audio Strap is a popular strap due to the fact it does have integrated audio, however it's not as popular as it once was due to pricing. 
 The Quest 2 has modular straps that allowed third party straps to exist, and as such other straps like the Bobo and Kiwi have been made far cheaper.

 You can get a Vive Deluxe Strap for 99 typically, but you also need a 3D printed adapter 
 If you do not have a 3d printer you will pay upwards of 20$ for the adapter.

fields.name: Info
fields.value:
__Included Battery__: No 
 __Included Audio__: Yes

embed.title: Reccomended Routers
embed.description:
The following routers have been reported to work reliably from a number of users.
 High End - Asus RT-AX86U (300 US$) 
Mid Range - Asus RT-AX55 (145 US$)
Low End - TP-Link Archer C6 or A6 (40 US$)

footer.text: We don't recommend TP-Link AX routers as they have lots of issues.

embeds.title: TPLink C6
embeds.description:
The C6 /A6 is a good dedicated router specifically for wireless VR usage.

You can find different variants of this such as the A6, and there is multiple versions of this router - the V2 and V3 are known to be good.

embed.title: Support is volunteer driven
embed.description:
Be patient, be civil, and be descriptive on your issues.

 All support is volunteer driven, we help who we can help, as we can help. Not everyone knows how to help you, and not everyone will.

 Be as descriptive as you can with your issue, it's a lot more likely someone will remember something if they see a keyword that helps them.

footer.text: Check #help-faq for information on asking for help.

fields.name: Asking in multiple channels
fields.value: Just don't do this - It's against the rules, it causes people to not want to help you, and it does nothing to get your answer faster.

embed.title: Sharing Screenshots of the Performance Overlay
embed.description: Render Resolution __per eye__

name: ipd
description: IPD and Its Importance in VR.

embed.title: IPD and Its Importance in VR.
embed.description: IPD is the distance between the pupils of your eyes, this is important for VR as you need to make sure you are within the limits of that device otherwise you will experience eye strain, focus issues, and other related issues.

fields.name: Common IPD Ranges
fields.value:
Quest 2 - 3 Settings - 58mm, 63mm, 68mm (+/-2.5mm in each direction)
Valve Index - 58-70mm
Reverb G2 - 60-68mm
[VRCompare for More headsets](https://vr-compare.com/)

fields.name: How to check?
fields.value:
There's a few ways to check, but the two main ways are checking with a ruler in front of your mirror or using the app [EyeMeasure](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/eyemeasure/id1417435049)
 You would want the 'Far' IPD from this app.

fields.name: Ruler Method
fields.value:
Stand in front of a mirror and hold a ruler up to your nose, such that the measuring edge runs directly underneath both your pupils.
lose your right eye and look directly at your left eye. Move the ruler such that the “0” mark appears directly underneath the center of your left pupil. Try to keep the ruler still for the next step.
Close your left eye and look directly at your right eye. The mark directly underneath the center of your right pupil is your IPD.

embed.title: General Minimum Specs for VR
embed.description:
OS: Windows 10
CPU: Intel i3-6100 / AMD Ryzen 3 1200, FX4350 or greater
RAM: 8GB+ RAM
GPU: NVIDIA GTX 1050 Ti / AMD Radeon RX 470 or greater
USB Ports: 1x 3.0 port
Free Space: 35GB on C:

fields.name: Recommended Minimum Specs for VR (Community Based)
fields.value:
OS: Windows 10
CPU: Intel i5-7500 / AMD Ryzen 5 1600 or greater
RAM: 12GB+ RAM
GPU: NVIDIA GTX 1660 Super / AMD Radeon RX 5600XT or greater
USB Ports: 1x 3.1 port
Free Space: 35GB on C:

fields.name: Detailed info
fields.value:
You can find detailed minimums below, please note minimum does not mean you can play every game.
[Oculus Rift S Supported Specs](https://support.oculus.com/248749509016567)
[Oculus Link Supported Specs](https://support.oculus.com/444256562873335)
[Valve Index Supported Specs](https://support.steampowered.com/kb_article.php?ref=4061-QUZB-4602)

embed.title: Sidequest
embed.description: Sidequest is a widely known application that allows you to 'Sideload' 3rd party apps and modifications for your Quest.

fields.name: Do I need a VR ready PC?
fields.value: No, it does not require a VR ready PC to use, but does require a cable to connect your quest to your PC (2.0 or 3.0).

fields.name: Is it safe?
fields.value: It's accepted by Oculus and you can find information on how to install it [here](https://sidequestvr.com/setup-howto) with all setup instructions.

embed.title: Oculus Link
embed.description: Oculus Link is a feature built into the Quest that allows you to use your Quest as a PC VR headset while wired into a VR Ready PC.

fields.name: Can I play any VR game?
fields.value: You can generally play any Oculus Rift, or SteamVR title while on Link, as long as your PC is capable of running it.

fields.name: What's required?
fields.value: You need a VR Ready PC that meets the minimum specs, you can find out more detail [here](https://support.oculus.com/444256562873335/), as well as a USB 3.0 A or C to C cable, you can find more info about this with /linkcables.

embed.title: Air Link
embed.description: Air Link is the Wireless PCVR feature bring brought in [V28](https://www.oculus.com/blog/introducing-oculus-air-link-a-wireless-way-to-play-pc-vr-games-on-oculus-quest-2-plus-infinite-office-updates-support-for-120-hz-on-quest-2-and-more/)

fields.name: Requirements
fields.value:
1. [VR Ready PC](https://support.oculus.com/444256562873335), please note this is not a 100% of all hardware supported, better graphics cards than listed will work as well. 
2. 5Ghz AC or AX network with a wired connection to your PC.

fields.name: FAQ
fields.value:
1. **Is my internet good enough?:** Internet does not matter for Air Link, you only need good local connection.
2. **Can I play SteamVR on this?:** Yes, SteamVR is fully supported just like wired link.
3. **Is my router good enough?:** If you want more information, look up your routers model number and make sure it's AX or AC, or provide your model number in your thread.
4. **I'm having issues, where can I get help?:** Please create a thread using #help-faq.

embed.title: Sharing Screenshots of the Performance Overlay
embed.description:
1.) Go into the Settings tab in the Virtual Desktop menu in VR and make sure 'copy screenshots to desktop' is enabled.
2.) Go into the Streaming tab and check 'Show performance overlay'.
3.) Launch your VR game.
4.) Look for numbers that are turning orange.
5.) When you see this, hold right Oculus button + press right or left trigger to take a screenshot.

 The screenshot will be found on your desktop and you can share it here.

embed.title: USB C vs USB A
embed.description:
There is a common misconception on USB C and USB A being different speeds, however they are not the decider of speed.
There are different USB standards you should pay attention to on cables that will be the deciding factor if it will work for your Quest.

The Quest 1 and 2 both should be used with a USB 3.0 cables - also known as USB 3.1 Gen 1, and USB 3.2 Gen 1x1
You can find these types of cables on A and C through various retailers at various lengths.

For more information on examples of cables use the command /linkcables.

embed.title: Discord on Quest
embed.description:
Discord is only currently possible on Quest through either a sideloadable APK, or through the web browser.
However, this does not mean it can be used while in game, or doing any other tasks
It only works while it's open and focused as the quest does not allow background tasks.

embed.title: App Lab
embed.description: For information about app lab, please see [here](https://www.reddit.com/r/oculusquest/wiki/faq/applab).

embed.title: Virtual Desktop
embed.description:
Virtual Desktop is a Quest application that allows you to use your Desktop in VR, Watch Videos, as well as using it for Wireless PC VR a VR Ready PC.
For first time setup and general FAQ, please check out [this guide](https://reddit.com/r/OculusQuest/wiki/faq/virtualdesktop).

embed.title: Quest/Rift Crossbuy Apps
embed.description:
Rift and Quest have some games that support Crossbuy, and you can find that list [here](https://www.oculus.com/experiences/quest/section/2335732183153590/#/?_k=l5u635).
 Please note that crossbuy can only apply between Oculus PC and Mobile stores, and this does not include Steam.

embed.title: Quest/Rift Crossplay Apps
embed.description:
Rift and Quest have some games that support Cross Play (Playing between a rift and a quest without Link on different accounts), and you can find that list [here](https://www.reddit.com/r/oculus/wiki/crossplay)
Please note this is a community maintained list and will not always be accurate.

embed.title: Link Cables
embed.description: The community has worked together to make a community list of cables that you can check out [here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1NZCIkucxceUkF9OesY0MGDoDDgiRZ3P-7wetQ_i9ZLw/edit?ouid=107263133346368975689&usp=sheets_home&ths=true)

embed.title: Valve Support
embed.description: You can try contacting Valve via a ticket [here](https://help.steampowered.com/en/wizard/HelpWithGame/?appid=250820).

embed.title: Oculus/Meta Support
embed.description:
You can try contacting Oculus Support via either a ticket or live chat [here](https://tickets.oculusvr.com/hc/en-us/requests/new).
If live chat is available, it will show up in the bottom right hand corner.

embed.title: Quest Manual Update
embed.description: You can find a guide on how to manually update [here](https://www.reddit.com/r/oculusquest/wiki/guides/manualupdate) if you have a copy of the firmware you need.

embed.title: Don't ask to ask, just ask
embed.description:
When you ask 'hey can anyone or someone help me', this can be seen as bad form.
 The best way to get assistance is to ask your entire question with details, in a relevant channel
 There are plenty of reasons why people that do have the knowledge would not admit to it, but by asking the full question you are asking people to answer a question, not take responsibility to answer the question they may not have the answer to.

embed.title: Half Life Alyx - Stutter Fix
embed.description: Right-click Half-Life: Alyx in Steam then click Properties, in 'General' click in launch options and paste the following: ```+vr_fidelity_level_auto 0 +vr_fidelity_level 3```

embed.title: Quest Factory Reset
embed.description: If you need to factory reset your Quest, please enable [cloud sync](https://support.oculus.com/articles/in-vr-experiences/oculus-features/cloud-sync/) and then follow [these](https://support.oculus.com/articles/fix-a-problem/troubleshoot-headsets-and-accessories/troubleshooting-factory-reset-quest-2/) instructions on the factory reset.

embed.title: Quest Cloud Backup
embed.description: You can see what games you own that support cloud backup [here](https://secure.oculus.com/my/cloud-backup/).
